title: 107_s2844
content: The Act is titled the "Incentives to Educate American Children (I Teach) Act of 2002". Congress finds that there is a need for 2,000,000 new teachers in the next decade. The No Child Left Behind Act requires States to recruit qualified teachers by 2006, but rural and high-poverty schools struggle to attract and retain teachers. Rural education is crucial for overall education performance. According to the Rural School and Community Trust 2000 report, rural education is crucial for overall education performance in 25 States, with 14% of America's school children attending rural schools. A 2000 study by the Education Trust shows that high poverty schools are twice as likely to lack certified teachers in their fields, requiring special assistance to meet the goals of the No Child Left Behind Act of 2001. High poverty schools are twice as likely to lack certified teachers in their fields, emphasizing the need for special assistance to meet the goals of the No Child Left Behind Act of 2001. The National Board for Professional Teaching Standards, established in 1987, aims to set high standards for accomplished teachers. The National Board for Professional Teaching Standards sets high standards for accomplished teachers through a rigorous certification process. Over 16,000 teachers from all 50 states have completed this certification. Recent data from the Accomplished Teaching Validation Study shows that teachers certified by the National Board for Professional Teaching Standards outperform their non-certified peers on 11 out of 13 key measures of teaching expertise. Additionally, teacher salaries have remained stagnant over the past decade, with two-thirds of states not meeting the national average salary of $40,582. Teacher salaries have stagnated over the past decade, with 2/3 of states below the national average of $40,582. The Act aims to incentivize teachers to work in rural or high-poverty schools and provide tax credits for National Board certification. The Act aims to provide tax credits for teachers achieving National Board certification to recruit and retain highly qualified teachers in public schools, especially in rural or high-poverty areas. SEC. 35 introduces a tax credit for individuals teaching in elementary and secondary schools in high poverty or rural areas and for certified teachers. A tax credit is introduced for eligible teachers in high poverty or rural area schools, allowing a credit against the tax imposed for the taxable year. The credit amount is based on the eligible academic year ending during that year. In general, eligible teachers in high poverty or rural area schools can receive a tax credit of $1,000 for performing services during the academic year. This applies to public schools where at least 75% of students receive free or reduced-cost lunches. Eligible teachers in high poverty or rural area schools can receive a tax credit of $1,000 if at least 75% of students receive free or reduced-cost lunches or the school has a School Locale Code of 7 or 8. Teachers must be certified by the National Board for Professional. Eligible teachers in high poverty or rural area schools can receive a tax credit of $1,000 if certified by the National Board for Professional Teaching Standards. For those in schools with high poverty or in rural areas, the amount increases to $2,000. The applicable amount for eligible teachers in high poverty or rural area schools is $2,000. An eligible teacher is defined as a kindergarten through grade 12 classroom teacher in a public elementary or secondary school on a full-time basis. Elementary and secondary schools have the meanings given by the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965. The terms 'elementary school' and 'secondary school' are defined by the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965. An eligible academic year is any academic year ending in a taxable year after December 31, 2002. Amendments are made to section 1324(b) of title 31, United States Code. Amendments are made to section 1324(b) of title 31, United States Code, and the table of sections for subpart C of part IV of subchapter A of chapter 1 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is updated. Tax credit for individuals teaching in high poverty or rural areas and certified teachers. Effective Date: Amendments apply to academic years ending in taxable years beginning after December 31, 2002.
